1.content:
It was a nice day. The birds were chirping, the sun was shinning, the wind was blowing through the leaves of the trees.

Stopping for a second in front of the old hospital you look up at the proud old building. Earlier that month they had finally finished building the new hospital just up the road. The last patients had been moved out just the day before. Going up the walk you decide to take a look around inside. As you open the door you are hit by a gust of wind that seems to be blowing you inside. Holding on for your life you try to pull away. Unfortunately the tired old doorframe gives under the stress and you are swept inside.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~


Opening your eyes you notice that your are still in the old hospital. The odd thing is that all around you people are moving about as though the hospital was still active. Confused by this you shake your head and look at the clock and see that the time was now 7:00 PM. Beside the clock you spot a calendar that joyously states that the year is 1988.

12.content:
"Oh my God, Mom!?" you screeched, gazing at the feint reflection in a nearby window, seeing that instead of your very familiar 19 year old body that you'd spent all your life getting used to, you were somehow staring back at the image of your own mother, your own mother if she had been 20 years younger! Still reeling from the shock of the reflection, you looked down over your body, examining it to see if you were somehow hallucinating, discovering much to your horror that you weren't. Your arms were slender and smooth, your hands delicate and feminine with long red painted fingernails, you could see and feel long brown hair cascading down your shoulders, as well as two large prominent mounds sticking out from your chest, blocking the view of your feet.

"Oh shit! This is some kind of dream!" you told yourself, falling backwards onto the floor, the shock being too much for you to take.

"Miss, are you okay?" you heard a voice ask, as you saw a man quickly approach you, seemingly rather concerned, but not half as concerned as you yourself felt; somehow finding yourself in the body of your own mother 20 years in the past.

"Whu-what's going on?" you asked him, feeling very feint, your body having turned to jelly underneath the light blue flowery dress you now appeared to be wearing, as he lifted you up off the floor.

"You just had a little fall, that's all," he told you, leading you over to one of the hospital benches nearby. "Are you feeling okay? What's your name?"

Focusing properly on his face in an effort to stop yourself from passing out right there in terror, you saw that he was a doctor, and he began examining both of your eye, laying his hand on your brow to make sure you were alright. Clearly you were not alright though, you were absolutely petrified, with no idea how or why this had happened, half believing you were just dreaming, the other half knowing that this was actually happening.

"Miss? Can you tell me your name?" he asked again, waiting for a response.

You weren't sure what to tell him, obviously he wouldn't believe you if you said your name was Henry and you were from the future, seeing as you were now in the body of a 20 year old woman, and would probably have you locked up. Instead you just quietly stared down at your mother's left hand, noticing the absence of any sort of wedding ring and figuring this must be before she'd married your father, nervously muttering out, "Sarah...Sarah Mittle," figuring it best, until you figured out what had happened or how to turn back.
12.title: Mother from the past

choices: Ethel knows who you really are, and gives you an important message.
During the conversation, you swap bodies with Ethel.
122.content:
Using your mother's maiden name seems to do the trick. The doctor's eyes flash in recognition. Flipping a page on his clipboard, his mustache bristles. "I see. Mittle. You must be here to visit Ethel, then?"

You have no idea where you are (aside from a hospital wing, apparently), the name of any of the doctors, nurses, and patients walking about, or most importantly why you're suddenly in your mother's younger body. You strongly suspect you're in the past, sometime in the 1980s given your mother's youthful appearance and the fashion worn by everyone around here. Doc Martens, parachute pants, and big foofy hair not being popular since then. You know your Mom and Dad buried some of those relics way, way back in the closet at home for nostalgia.

Nodding silently, feeling your mother's curly hair bounce about your shoulders, you stand up unsteadily. Swaying for a moment, you resist the urge to grab your new hefty, perky breasts and follow the doctor down the hallway. You hear your mom's pumps clicking smartly on the tile until you stop in front of a patient room.

"She's awake now." The doctor announced, adding gently, "It's good that you came, Sarah. Please, take as much time as you need." He turned the doorknob and beckoned you inside.

Oxygen tanks. The rhythmic humming of a respirator as it compresses and decompresses. Intravenous tubes, needles, and packets dangling from a rack behind the bed. A box television set, currently turned on, with wire antennae and dial knobs in the corner of the smallish room. The whole room smells like anti-septic. The curtains are partly drawn, and the lamp next to the bed emits a milky yellow light, even though it still looks like daytime outside.

Laying in bed: A small old woman with pale skin and a few patches of curly white hair sitting atop her head. The hospital blankets are thick and warm and lay heavily on top of her skeleton-like body, which is dressed in a drab green gown with polka dots.

You approached the woman, not knowing what to say or even who she was, wondering whether this was all a dream and you might wake up in your own bed, in your own body, back in the present day.

And then you saw the flowers.

There they were: Purple Lilacs, in a vase on the table on the other side of the bed next to the window.

You never met Ethel Mittle; she died before you were born. Everything you knew about your maternal great-grandmother, therefore, came from stories passed down from your mother, which wasn't very much. The only time Grandma Ethel was ever mentioned was during family reunions along with a spate of other names you hardly recognised. You remember her appearing in slideshows and the occasional homemade film reel, but she was always in the background, never the centre of attention it seemed.

But one thing stood out more than anything else was how much she loved lilacs. She and her husband, that's your great-grandfather Dean, always had a fresh crop of lilac flowers in their old house. Ethel loved them, and Dean loved Ethel, so they never went without them according to your mother. Even most of Ethel's clothes had the same light purple colour, although most of her photos in the family scrapbook were black-and-white. Their old house was about three hours' drive away, where Ethel grew a whole patch of lilacs in the garden.

So the lilacs resting in the vase made perfect sense to you now. You confirmed that this woman was, in fact, your great-grandmother, by viewing the notes scribbled with an erasable marker on a whiteboard on the wall. Her name, medications, Nurse's name, and surgical schedule were listed neatly on the whiteboard.

Along with today's date: 14 September, 1988.

Bloody hell! That would make your mom 20 years old.

You aren't sure whether she met Dad by this time, hoping to awaken from this hyper-realistic dream before knowing for sure.

This whole time, Ethel hadn't noticed you enter the room. She was watching a news programme on the TV. The production quality is terrible, and you swear the news anchor referred to the Soviet Union a moment ago:

         In response to reported political instability in Soviet-bloc countries such as Poland and Czechoslovakia, General Secretary Gorbachev will be unveiling a new policy entitled glasnost, Russian for 'openness.' The response from the United Nations has been mostly positive, viewed by many as another step towards...

Your mouth feels dry, and your heart is thumping within your chest. What do you say to an old woman you've never met before? A woman who you know is about to die?

You're not particularly religious, but you can't shake the feeling that there's something meaningful about this whole situation. Like, maybe God or Jesus or somebody else placed you here for a reason? If this is all just a dream, it's certainly the most vivid dream you've ever had. Right down to the empty feeling in your crotch down below!

You continue pretending to be Sarah, Ethel's granddaughter. Reasoning that she, like anyone else, wouldn't understand why a 20-year-old woman would suddenly claim to be her own 19-year-old son!

How does the conversation go?

Wondering why you can't hear anything you wipe tears from your eyes and turn around to see a policeman arresting a 3- something man standing on the other side of a bed from you. The man says something to you but again there is no sound.

You jump when a hand rests on your shoulder. Looking up you see an elderly gentleman, tears welling up in his eyes, desperately trying to smile reassuringly in your direction.

"What is going on?" you ask, still baffled as to why you can't hear anything (even your own voice).

What surprised you even more was the reaction of the old man. He jumped back, apparently very surprised. Then stepping forwards, he grasp your delicate hands in his own and calmly treid to answer your question. Unfortunately you could still not hear a thing. After a bit the old man seemed to have given up trying to explain something to you and just started to hug you tightly.

"Am I Deaf?" you wonder, but as you had yet to get used to the lack of sound you say it out loud, causing a repeat of the earlier outburst of the old man. This time, from his body language you determine that yes, you are deaf and that your body had never previously uttered a word.

"Are you crazy?" You ask the lady next to you as you stop the car near a local diner.

"No, I'm in love." She tells you.

"You switched your husband with me? That doesn't look to me like you love him." You tell her looking right into her eyes.

"Well, I can't help it." She tells you as she closes her eyes and cries a little. "I caught him cheating a few days ago with some floozy. I didn't want our relationship to end. What would our families say? What would our friends say?"

You get the feeling this lady only stayed with this man, because of social status. But as your friends always told you, you have a soft feeling for women who are crying.

You know you are going to regret this, as you place your hand on the woman her shoulder. "There, there, I didn't mean it that bad."

"You really mean it?" She says looking at you with her eyes still a bit wet.

"Yes, I do. Now could you at least tell your name?" You ask her.

"Jane Massenhall, and you are my husband Max Massenhall." She tells you showing her ring to you.

Then you remember what would happen twenty years from now on. Max was caught cheating with his secretary which made him divorce his wife. info.brief_description: You are swept back in time 20 years into someone else's body with the power to swap bodies
info.description:
Your name is Henry Heckleberry. You are 19 years old. Your mother's name is Sarah (Mittle) Heckleberry and your father's name is Jacob Heckleberry Jr. You have a girlfriend who is one year older than you named Marsha Jones.

Walking home one day you go by the old hospital. for some reason you decide to go inside. When you walk through the doors of the recently abandoned building you are thrown into a time-vortex. When you open your eyes you find yourself 20 years in the past, in someone else's body and with the ability to swap bodies with people in that time period just by thinking about it.

No killing (of the main character or his parents' younger selves).
Try to keep good grammar (in dialogue bad grammar is fine if you want to emphasize an accent or something).
No personality changes at all.
if there is a list of more than 2 items try to keep it open for more additions
